s1.name: joram CVS Version, no tag
s1.p: Getting Joram through CVS without specifying a tag allows to get the latest tagged version with the latest corrections and updates.

ul.li:
Blocking AdminItf.stopServer method (as noticed
here). The processing of this method disapeared from the administration topic server side since release 3.5, probably due to an invalid CVS merge. The code is back now in class fr.dyade.aaa.mom.dest.AdminTopicImpl.

s1.name: joram3_6_0 (August 7, 2003)
s1.p: This version provides the kJORAM libraries allowing J2ME applications to connect to the JORAM platform.

ul.li: Major modifications occured to the CVS tree. kJORAM sources are located in the src/com/scalagent directory. JORAM samples have been moved to the samples/src/joram directory, and the configuration files directory is now samples/config. The kJORAM samples are located in the samples/src/kjoram directory.

Improvement of the closing of a dead connection; particularly, calling Connection.close() within the onException method of an ExceptionListener would generate an infinite closing loop. The impacted class is fr.dyade.aaa.joram.Driver.
setConfig(...) method in fr.dyade.aaa.agent.AgentServer has now a public access for configuration purposes; calling it after the server has been started throws an exception.

ClassCastException occuring in fr.dyade.aaa.mom.proxies.ProxyImpl when subscribing to a non-readable topic, found by
Prashanth Kasturi. The bug is corrected, the impacted class is fr.dyade.aaa.mom.proxies.ProxyImpl.

s1.name: joram3_5_0 (June 2003, 24th)
s1.p: This version provides a totally refactored message persistence management.

s2.name: Modifications
s2.p: Modifications mainly occured in the destinations' and proxy's algorithms. Check packages fr.dyade.aaa.mom.dest and fr.dyade.aaa.mom.proxies. Check also the new class fr.dyade.aaa.mom.messages.PersistenceModule.

s1.name: joram3_4_3 (June 2003, 17th)
s1.p: This version provides a new Monolog initialization allowing a better integration of Joram within Jonas.

s2.name: Modifications
s2.p: Modified classes are fr.dyade.aaa.agent.AgentServer and fr.dyade.aaa.util.Debug.

s1.name: joram3_4_2 (May 2003, 28th)
s1.p: Compared with the 3_4_1 release, this version introduces monitoring methods and corrects bugs as described below.

ul.li: Introduction of a monitoring interface and reference implementation. A first set of methods allow to list the destinations, users of a given server, the readers, writers on a given destination, etc. Documentation will be updated. Impacted packages are fr.dyade.aaa.mom.admin, fr.dyade.aaa.mom.comm, fr.dyade.aaa.mom.dest, fr.dyade.aaa.mom.proxies and fr.dyade.aaa.joram.admin.

New administration method for stopping a server ( AdminItf.stopServer(int serverId)). This method allows to stop a given server from a connected administrator. Impacted classes are fr.dyade.aaa.agent.ProxyAgent, fr.dyade.aaa.mom.admin.StopServerRequest, fr.dyade.aaa.mom.dest.AdminTopicImpl, fr.dyade.aaa.joram.admin.AdminItf and fr.dyade.aaa.joram.admin.AdminImpl.

Modification of the administration methods: they are now all synchronous, for improving the return of errors to the administrator. Impacted packages are: fr.dyade.aaa.joram.admin, fr.dyade.aaa.mom.comm, fr.dyade.aaa.mom.dest, fr.dyade.aaa.mom.proxies.
Modification of the Message class in the fr.dyade.aaa.mom.messages package: text and map bodies are not serialized anymore for opening Joram to the ability to route non Java clients' messages.

Following
Knut's feedback, the setting of JNDI's URL has evolved: java.naming.provider.url might be set as host:port and not only as joram://host:port. The impacted class is NamingContextFactory in the fr.dyade.aaa.jndi2.client package.

Bug concerning expiring messages in queues, found by Lorenzo Scantamburlo: already delivered messages, but not yet acknowledged, when expiring, were removed and a deliverables counter was wrongly decreased. This resulted in having remaining messages on the queue not delivered until further messages arrived. It is now corrected; the impacted class is QueueImpl in the fr.dyade.aaa.mom.dest package.

Bug in bytes and stream messages: sequentially modifying and sending an instance of one of those messages resulted in always sending the same original message. The impacted classes are BytesMessage and StreamMessage in the fr.dyade.aaa.joram package.

Following
Huey-Siang Kam's feedback, a bug in Joram's administration has been corrected: it was not possible, with the AdminItf.updateUser() method, to only update a user's password, rather than both its name and password. Now, it is. The impacted class is AdminTopicImpl in the fr.dyade.aaa.mom.dest package.

Bug in serial sending of a message with a transacted session: clearing an already sent (but not commited) message's properties, was actually clearing the properties (instead of clearing only the properties for the sending to come). The impacted class is Message in the fr.dyade.aaa.mom.messages package.

Following
Doug's feedback, a JNDI bug has been corrected: serializable objects may now be bound in a server without the need for the server to "know" the objects' classes. The following packages should be updated: fr.dyade.aaa.agent, fr.dyade.aaa.ip, fr.dyade.aaa.jndi2.

s1.name: joram3_4_1
s1.p: This version is a maintenance version of the 3.4.0 release. It has been tagged for allowing the integration of an up-to-date Joram into JOnAS.

ul.li: NGNetwork class removed from fr.dyade.aaa.agent package for allowing compilation with jdk1.3.
Bug corrected in the fr.dyade.aaa.mom.proxies.ProxyImpl class and concerning XA rollbacks.

s2.name: Support of SOAP as a client/server Communication Protocol
s2.p: This version is only available in CVS with tag joram3_4_0. So far, Joram provided a TCP link between its clients and servers. Now, it also provides a SOAP link, based on HTTP and XML.
For more info on SOAP, check W3C's SOAP site.

The support of the SOAP protocol led to re-architecturing the server side proxies (fr.dyade.aaa.mom.proxies) and client side connection classes (fr.dyade.aaa.joram.Connection, fr.dyade.aaa.joram.Driver, fr.dyade.aaa.joram.tcp, fr.dyade.aaa.joram.soap).
Documentation is available, samples have been added for testing. Testing requires the use of a servlet container such as Apache's Tomcat.

ul.li:
NullPointerException occuring from time to time in the server's side proxy of a subscriber, found by
Laura Foster. This bug occured when removing expired messages delivered by a topic.

s2.name: Maintenance Release of joram3_3_0
s2.p: This version comes as packages and is tagged joram3_3_1 in CVS. It is similar to the joram3_3_0 version except that it corrects a few bugs.

ul.li:
Non serializable ConnectionFactory objects, found by
Tony Thompson. FactoryConfiguration and JoramUrl classes were not serializable and thus, the serialization of a ConnectionFactory instance would fail.

Bug in fr.dyade.aaa.agent.A3CMLDomain, found by
Tony Thompson. Launching an AgentServer with no DTD could not work.

s2.name: New Administration Protocol
s2.p: This version of JORAM includes a totally refactored administration protocol. Administration is now based on JMS communication and is much more flexible than the past implementation. The new administration implementation comes with a new administration interface. Old administration codes should go on working even if they now use deprecated methods.

ul.li:
Timeout in MessageConsumer.receive not compliant, found by
Gerald Schroeder. A MessageConsumer.receive(timeOut) would not return if the connection it belongs to was in stopped mode, even if the timer expired.

Incorrect behaviour of temporary destinations, found by
Armin Schieber. A client building a temporary destination from the Message.getJMSReplyTo() method was able to consume messages from the temporary destination, and also to delete it, even if it did not belong to the connection which actually created the temporary destination. Also, it was not possible to retrieve a temporary destination binded in JNDI.

A dead message queue is a destination getting undeliverable messages. Messages might be considered undeliverable because they expired before delivery, because they were sent on a non accessible destination or because they are constantly denied when consumed.

According to the JMS specification, topics might have a hierarchical structure allowing clients to subscribe or publish to given subtopics. Joram's fully distributed structure allows a topic hierarchy to be spread over many servers.

s2.name: Enhancements
s2.p: In order to prevent a Joram platform to be overloaded by a heavily producing client, a flow control mechanism has been added.

ul.li:
Timeout in MessageConsumer.receive not compliant, found by
Gerald Schroeder. A MessageConsumer.receive(0) behaved as a receiveNoWait() instead of behaving as a receive() (by waiting indefinitely for a message).

Listener not active if set after its connection was started, found by Gerald Schroeder. When setting a listener on a consumer belonging to a connection already started, the session thread for distributing the asynchronous deliveries was actually never started.

Connection not properly closed when failing, found by
Roy. In the case of a connection failure, the related Connection object and its resources were not properly closed.

Incorrect BytesMessage and StreamMessage implementations, found by
Mark Trumpler. BytesMessage and StreamMessage were wrongly behaving in the case of multiple sendings, modified or not. Also, their readBytes(...) methods were wrong.

Messages never delivered in the case of an incorrect listener removal, found by
Gerald Schroeder. When a listener is removed client side (by calling setMessageListener(null)), messages that reach the connection are denied. However, if the connection is stopped, the message were stored server side until it was started again. If the connection was never started, and also never closed, the messages were kept there for ever, and thus never delivered.

MessageProducers synchronized with the destinations, found by
Jan Kester. This incorrect behaviour was encountered in distributed configurations, when a producer client was connected to a server and produced a message destinated to a destination located on an other server. If this latest server was down, the producer would block because of a synchronous call to the destination to check the access permission of the producer.
